newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crudes slide as refiners trim runs.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crudes slide as refiners trim runs.

text.p: North Sea crudes slid on Wednesday as a handful of European refiners cut throughputs in response to poor margins and benchmark Dated Brent was pulled lower by a swaps-related deal, trading sources said.
"The market's looking a lot weaker today. There seem to be real run cuts and not just talk of them," said a North Sea producer.
An end-August Dated Brent cargo moved at a discount of 13 cents to Sept Brent paper in what traders described as a deal designed to benefit the seller's Contracts-for-Difference (CFDs) position.
Sept Brent barrels fetched Sept flat early on Wednesday. One Brent cargo, loading Sept 5-7, was due to turn wet.
Other grades were also under pressure from reduced refinery demand. Refineries in France, Britain and Italy have already cut back crude throughputs, traders said.
A French oil company sold a Sept 17 cargo of Norwegian Ekofisk to a British refiner for about Dated Brent +37/+38 cents, down from trade last Thursday at Dated Brent +45 cents.
Oseberg and Statfjord cargoes were also said to have moved at lower prices but exact pricing details could not be confirmed.
Brent intermonth paper spreads were steady after slipping a couple of cents in early talk, with Sep/Oct at +45/+48 cents and Oct/Nov at +38/+42 cents.
Next week's dates were also unchanged from early talk with Aug 26-30 valued at Oct Brent +27/+31 cents.
Demand for West African crudes perked up with barrels moving both to the U.S. and the East late on Tuesday.

A second decade September VLCC of Bonny Light/Medium and Odudu moved to Korea, traders said. All the Bonny Light/Medium cargoes in September were now sold and the grades were valued at Dated Brent +50-53/25 cents, they added.
